conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame.
The wire frame is a semi-circular shape with radius \( r \), consisting of a semi-circular part and a straight part.
The length of the semi-circular part is \( \pi r \), and the length of the straight part is \( 2r \). Therefore, the total length of the wire frame is \( L = \pi r + 2r \).
The wire frame is connected to a direct current (DC) constant voltage power supply, and the voltage \( V \) across the wire frame is the same as the voltage supplied by the power supply.
The current \( I \) in the wire frame can be found using Ohm's law, \( I = \frac{V}{R} \), where \( R \) is the total resistance of the wire frame.

The force on a segment of wire of length \( L \) carrying current \( I \) in a magnetic field \( B \) is given by \( F = I L B \sin \theta \), where \( \theta \) is the angle between the current and the magnetic field.
For the straight part of the wire frame, the current is parallel to the magnetic field, so the force is \( F_{\text{straight}} = I \cdot 2r \cdot B \).
The force on the semi-circular part of the wire frame is \( F_{\text{semi-circular}} = I \cdot \pi r \cdot B \).
Since the current is the same in both parts, the force on the semi-circular part can also be expressed as \( F_{\text{semi-circular}} = \frac{\pi r}{2r} \cdot F = \frac{\pi}{2} F \).

The total force on the entire wire frame is \( F_{\text{total}} = F_{\text{straight}} + F_{\text{semi-circular}} = I \cdot 2r \cdot B + I \cdot \pi r \cdot B = I \cdot (2r + \pi r) \cdot B = I \cdot (\pi r + 2r) \cdot B = L \cdot I \cdot B \).
From \( F = I \cdot 2r \cdot B \), we get \( I \cdot B = \frac{F}{2r} \).
The total force is \( F_{\text{total}} = L \cdot I \cdot B = (\pi r + 2r) \cdot \frac{F}{2r} = \frac{(\pi + 2) F}{2} \).
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is \( \boxed{\frac{(\pi + 2)F}{2}} \).
